segments.text: This is an interview with Lonnie Doggett by Ruth Ann Kirtland on December the 5th at Giddings, Texas, concerning his tour of duty in Vietnam and his feelings about Vietnam, the Vietnam War.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge, I am asking him to donate this tape to me or to the Texas A&M oral history collection in the university archives.
And he has agreed to this.
Have you not?
Yes.
Could you tell me where you were born and what your birth date is?
I was born in Ballinger, Texas on August 31, 1944.
And what's your education?
Two years of college at Angelo State University.
And what was your degree you were pursuing?
Agricultural.
And what's your profession now?
My profession is I'm a drilling fluids engineer.
Have you been in the oil business very long?
About 12 years.
That's long.
It's quite long.
Okay, what branch of the service were you in?
United States Air Force.
And how long were you in the United States Air Force?
Four years.
What rank were you in the Air Force?
I was a buck sergeant.
Air Force?
Mm-hmm.
What did you do in the Air Force?
I was a military policeman.
Isn't that called a security policeman?
Security policeman.
Is that what they called them then, or...?
Well, they still call them that.
They're all military police.
They're security police in the Air Force.
Mm-hmm.
Were you on the security side or the defense side, or didn't they have them separated?
No, they didn't have them separated.
Okay.
What year did you go to Vietnam?
I went in December of 1966.
And how long were you there?
A year.
The normal tour, did it?
Mm-hmm.
Could you tell me briefly what your duties were as a security policeman?
We were assigned to protect a base in South Vietnam.
It was our duty to protect that base, which was Ponsonute Air Force Base, and we were assigned to protect it.
Did you have any contact with the Arvin while you were there?
Could you give me your opinion of the effectiveness of the Arvin or whether they were ineffective?
The Arvin was, they were effective with what they had.
They were very effective.
You know, I don't know just exactly what you're saying, but the effectiveness that they had, I mean, they could do with whatever they had.
They could do with modern weapons.
They could do with primitive weapons and do a good job.
Well, when they sent the advisors over to Vietnam, they were supposed to be training the Arvin, is the way I understand it.
And this is why I ask you the question, if they were affected, did the training do them any good, or do you feel that it was just
their natural talents, the natural ability that they had as Vietnamese in the country.
You're talking basically about the South Vietnamese soldiers.
Yes.
We were fighting the North Vietnamese.
Right.
Well, the South Vietnamese were basically good soldiers, but they didn't have the discipline that American soldiers had, and that caused them a lot of times to fail in what they did.
Could you expand on that a little?
Discipline by meaning American troops or American forces in the past have had so much discipline.
Even in Vietnam, even though you're in a wartime situation, the discipline still is expressed in every phase, all the way down to you're still supposed to wear a uniform, right?
That's right.
Different things like that.
And you're still policed.
You're still told how to act and how to do.
And the RVAN didn't really have the discipline that we had.
And I think that's the reason American forces are as good fighters as they are, is because of the discipline that they had.
They recognized leadership.
And the RVAN didn't recognize leadership as much as, they just weren't as good a soldier as the American soldiers.
Did you come in contact with any of the helicopter pilots?
Oh, yeah.
Yes.
Did you happen to meet any of the Arvin helicopter pilots?
No.
Just American helicopter pilots.
What was your feelings about the American helicopter pilots and where they did their job?
I thought they were unbelievably good.
They were outstanding.
Did you go out into combat, or did you just stay at the Air Force base there?
No, we were involved in combat.
Another thing, too, you know, that people don't seem to understand, in Vietnam there's no such thing as going to the front.
There was no front.
I mean, if you were on Vietnamese soil, you were in a combat zone.
It didn't make any difference if you was in the streets in Saigon or if you were in the jungles around Tui Hoa or somewhere.
You were in a combat zone in every situation.
You were never out of a combat zone if you were in Vietnam.
So, you know, like us, even though we were on a base, we had 26 miles of perimeter to cover.
Over half of that perimeter was in the jungle.
So, you know, you could be inside the base and not be in a safe situation.
In the first place, the base belonged to the Vietnamese.
It didn't belong to the Americans.
So we were just visitors there.
We were.
When we landed in Vietnam, as soon as we got off the aircraft, we were told that we were guests in Vietnam and remember that we were guests.
Why do you think they told you that?
I don't know.
They didn't explain it.
They just said that.
They just told us.
They said that too.
It meant what they, you know, what it implied, that we were guests.
Did the Air Force ever go out into the fields?
Sure.
The Air Force probably has maybe not as many combat troops as the others.
But the military, one thing, your role in Vietnam didn't mean whatever you were trained for in the United States didn't mean that that's what you were going to do while you were in Vietnam.
If you were at FUCAT or TUIWA and you were in the Air Force Security Police, your job was to set up ambushes outside the perimeter.
A job you really wasn't trained to do, but a lot of people wasn't trained to do a lot of things they did.
All of us in the Security Police went to combat school before we went overseas, but you were involved
Like I said, we protected the base where we were at.
There was no one at us, just us.
And so we were charged with providing security for the perimeter.
We were to protect it against all aggression or whatever it was or wherever it came.
So you ought to be, and also we had to cover things that happened, aerial accidents in the jungle and that sort of thing.
Those were, we were charged with covering those.
What do you mean by charged with?
It was your duty.
You were called upon to do it.
What did this consist of?
Well, for instance, one time we had an F-4 Phantom and another Australian aircraft that collided in midair and they crashed in the jungle.
Those aircraft had to be secured to keep the enemy from taking what was on and off.
So they took like a hundred of us and sent us into the jungle to secure that...
that crash sign until they got off what they wanted off of them.
That particular one, they would pick so many men to go and you went and you were given
You know, you took whatever weapons you were supposed to.
Some people had machine gun M60s, some people had grenade launchers, some people had M16s.
And you went into that area and we stayed two or three days in max.
And, you know, at that time, in that particular one, it was during the monsoons, so the rains were heavy.
You were in the rice paddies.
So you secured a, you know, it was pitch dark because of the rain and the air support that you were supposed to have that dropped illumination flares at night to light up the area never showed.
And so you lay out there on the dikes and the rice paddies and try to protect that grass side.
The only problem is, is the Vietnamese, the village where we were at,
Those people knew they hated us.
And because they knew when we left, the VC would come in and kill them all.
If we commandeered the barns and whatnot, the radio setups and whatnot.
Well, why did they know?
Why would the VC come in and kill them in the village because you had been there?
Because Americans had been there.
Is this standard?
Sure.
Who ordered it?
The VC did it?
Did that mean that the people did not want to cooperate with you?
Oh, yeah.
They didn't want us there at all.
But we didn't have any choice.
We had to be there.
I mean, what a crash site there.
It had to be taken care of.
How did you feel about this?
Well, I didn't want people to be slaughtered, but I think we should have been there.
I think we had to be there.
Were you in any other villages in the course of your duties?
I was in other villages, not for the same thing.
Traveling through them, taking prisoners through them.
Did they get slaughtered, killed by the V.C.
after they went in there?
No.
It was just because of that crash of the Phantom?
Yeah.
Most of them were...
Villages like that were jungle villages, you know, out off of the roads and stuff.
Small villages with a small amount of people.
But the V.C.
would always, you know, if they came in after us.
But you knew they did because they watched you all the time you were there.
How did you feel about knowing that they were watching you all the time?
Well, it's not a good feeling, but, you know, it's something to begin with.
You know, when you arrive in Vietnam, or when I did,
You know, you see all the movies and you read all the books about war, but it's not the same as when you really get there.
And when you really get there, when I got there, you know, you're afraid.
You're really scared for your life.
You feel like that you, you know, you may die.
Then you're, you know, you're really scared for probably like a couple of months.
And then after that couple of months, then you're not afraid anymore.
You're afraid, but they've been bothering you anymore.
So you learn to accept, you know, the environment.
Just like, I guess, going to a new job or something.
After a while, you get to where you kind of just grow something, you know.
And the war did that.
And then when
You got close to going home, you started getting scared again because you knew you were going back home.
So the reality of losing your life came back.
You worried about something happening to you before you got the chance to go back home.
How did you feel about the Vietnamese one, the South Vietnamese?
I had a very poor opinion of the Vietnamese, the South Vietnamese.
Low opinion.
In what way?
Well, in the first place, we were not treated.
Security policemen had a five piastre bounty on them.
If you kill a security policeman, then you got five dollars.
Oh.
So, you know, the bounty on the security police, you know, we weren't real important when we got down to it.
But, you know, a pilot had a bounty on him.
An officer had a bounty on him.
And the South Vietnamese didn't treat us real well at all.
We worked jointly with the QCs, which were the Quang Cong, and that was Premier Ky's number one people.
They were Vietnamese military policemen.
These were the trainings, weren't they, that came in the United States at Michigan State, I believe?
Well, I don't know.
They were a training in the United States.
They were Quang Cong.
They were killers.
They were ruthless.
Every evening, we worked at night all the time.

And every night when we went on duty at guard mount, they would give us a security or intelligence report and tell us what the conditions of the perimeter was if we were in a grade two possible attack or whatever.
The one thing that they always told us, if we were to come under attack, to make sure that the Quanton were in front of us and never got behind us, because they couldn't be trusted.
In other words, they were saying that the Quanton...
They would shoot you.
That they would shoot you?
Yeah.
So... Why do you think they would do that?
Because some of them were loyal to the NARC.
Even though they were accused people, they were loyal to the NARC.
There was lots of people that were loyal to the NARC.
This must have been very frustrating, not being able to tell who was North and who was South, because they all looked alike.
Half of the guys that we worked with, the Vietnamese military police, were born in Hanoi.
They weren't even from the South.
They were brought down by the...
The families were still living in Hanoi, in the north.
So, you know, it made you kind of edgy when you were with these guys.
A lot of times,
They had a Vietnamese workforce that came in at night, like at 10 or 11 o'clock at night, maybe a little later.
And they were unloaded at the gate, and all of them had come in and worked through the night, civilians.
We could tell when we were going to be hit because those people wouldn't show up.
They all knew when we were going to be attacked.
Wouldn't that have been an advantage to the Americans?
knowing that.
The only problem is, instead of knowing it 24 hours ahead of time, you knew it maybe two hours ahead of time.
Well, did the officers act on this once they realized it, or did they just ignore it?
Oh, yeah, we always prepared.
Well, I'm talking about the officers.
The officers, you know, they're the bosses.
And there's been a lot of talk about the colonels, that people were out there working on careerism.
Do you understand what I mean when I say careerism?
Sure.
Did you find that...
I saw officers get decorated for things that never happened.
You know, that was...
I mean, I didn't see it all the time, but it happened real frequent.
In one instance, I saw a major get decorated for killing an enemy that a friend of mine killed.
And he didn't get in.
He got a purple heart.
But he didn't get any credit for the kills, but the major did.
You know, things like that happen.
But the way...
A lot of times if there was, like I was saying about the attack, if there was an attack, the QCs would know, but they wouldn't tell us.
And they would be running around everywhere.
That's the way we'd know.
They'd be excited and nervous and trying to prepare, and we would know something was up.
Well, didn't it occur to the officers after a little while that when those people didn't show up at 10 o'clock that there might be something?
Oh, yeah, we all knew that.
As soon as we saw it, we'd notify headquarters.
Immediately we'd go into combat preparation and be ready for anything.
What did your combat readiness consist of?
That would mean deploying troops on the perimeters, covering air,

our important areas covering those making sure that we were protected and all which we were usually anyway what were you protected with what kind of equipment what kind of conventional weapons conventional weapons and these ones i've heard they weren't too too successful against the dc well yeah our weapons were affected the m16
The M60, I don't think there was any better machine gun than the M60 machine gun.
So they really were effective against them.
Weapons, yeah, they were effective.
You could do a real nice job with an M60 machine gun, an M16.
Now, we had problems with them to begin with.
The M16 was bad about jamming.
The only problem with that is the M16, you can't unjam an M16 like you can a bolt-action rifle.
A regular bolt-action rifle, you can take your knife out or something and pull the case out of the barrel.
You can't do that on the M16.
So what'd you do?
You threw it away.
Threw the weapon away.
Threw it away or got you another one or whatever you had to do.
So they started issuing rods with them.
It was kind of primitive.
But it was nice to have if you needed to get a gun.
So they issued rods with them, and then we had some more problems with them.
But all in all, it was an ammunition problem, and it was, I think, somewhat taken care of.
First M16 I had when I was there jammed a lot, and then I traded it for another M16, and I got good results out of it.
Sometimes you just get a bad one.
When did you get the jungle boots issued to you?
When I got there.
So they did have them when you got there?
We got issued a set of jungle boots, but we couldn't get fatigues or jungle fatigues they didn't have.
They didn't have the camming?
Well, we were supposed to have them, but they didn't have them.
The only thing is you could go to the black market in Saigon and buy anything you wanted to.
We couldn't even get ponchos for the monsoon, reindeer.
You couldn't buy underwear.
You couldn't buy it.
It was supposed to be issued.
You had to ask, you know, if you needed things like that, you rode home and someone would send you whatever you needed.
Are you saying that they didn't even have any ponchos that you had to buy them on the black market?
Right.
How much did they cost you on them?
It just depended on where and who you bought them from.
Approximately.
Well, you could buy one for $20.
American money, no doubt.
No.
See, you weren't allowed American money in Vietnam.
You only had military pay certificates.
If you got caught with American money, you went to jail.
Why was this?
to protect the currency in the United States, not have it depreciated.
Go ahead.
So they had the camouflage fatigues there on the black market, but the United States government did not have an issue to you at that time.
This was in 1966.
You could get anything, military, lots of things, on the black market that you couldn't get from our suppliers.
Well, they didn't even have them in the United States at that time for the military, for the security police.
They didn't have them until later on.
See, even Jeeps.
For the first six months, we ate sea rations.
That's all we had to eat.
I lost 40 pounds in six months when I got there.
I wasn't hungry, but, you know, didn't have anything to eat.
We ate sea rations, we ate them once a day.
Every can of sea rations we had was made in 1947.
It must have tasted lovely.
Well, it's canned, you know.
Well, how come you only got fed once a day?
It's just the only time we ate was once a day.
Didn't you get kind of hungry other times a little?
Yeah, you could find, I ate lots of monkey meat when I was there.
Monkey meat?
What did that taste like?
Well, then it tasted pretty good.
I don't know what it tastes like now, but it tasted fairly good then.
So, but they ate lots of monkeys.
And so you'd have a Vietnamese guard to get you a monkey sandwich.
Well, when did they start, got it, long before this, they're supposed to have had good meals served on the bases.
Well, we didn't have any chow halls or anything.
There's the, the... We did later on.
...papaganda.
that's put out before this.
They said you had that before that.
Right.
Sometime before that.
The field troops, the combat troops that were mobile would come through sometimes.
Well, like anybody, the infantry or whoever it was.
And they would have cases of steaks that they couldn't cook because they didn't stop long enough to cook them.
But they couldn't get C-rations.
And we could get all the C-rations we wanted, but we couldn't buy a stake anywhere.
So we would trade.
That made sense.
Okay, what about your commanding officers and the headquarters?
Because obviously it was the headquarters command who you were, right?
There was 7th Air Force Headquarters there.
Okay.
Okay, what about their eating?
Do they eat the sea rations?
You don't know?
Because General Westmoreland said that the troops were being fed hot meals at the bases.
I don't have a very high opinion of General Westmoreland either.
Would you care to expand on that a little bit?
Well, I just, you know, General Westmoreland was our commander.
Everybody's commander.
But Westmoreland and his command was lying to the United States about a lot of things about Vietnam, as everybody knows by now.
They do know now, but they didn't have... You know, we were...
I remember in May of 1966, during Operation Cedar Falls and Junction City,
They had over 5,000 casualties during that month.
The reason I know that is because all the bodies came through in front of us.
The choppers brought in the bodies because they'd bring them in there and put them in military caskets and sent them home.
And so we got all of the bodies in because we'd have to
Transport, they'd have to transport them through.
But they reported like, I don't remember now, 100 or 200 casualties for that month.
You mean what General S. Moreland reported?
Well, his command.
His command reported, well, as commander, whatever they say is his responsibility, I'm sure aware.
You know, that was one particular instance that stood out in my mind because I remember that so well.
One reason I lost a good friend during that.
during that time, during those operations.
But there was so many that died and so few that was reported to the people.
But I knew, of course, that I had a fit, but I knew we lost that many in that small town.
Do you think this was a deliberate cover-up on the part of Westmoreland, or do you think it came from the President of the United States?
I don't know.
I think it was probably both, because my opinion of Lyndon Johnson is not any higher than General Westmoreland.
And he was also the president while I was in Vietnam.
Yes, I know.
And I was a presidential guard for him when I came back to the States.
How did you feel about that?
I'm going to deviate just a moment since you brought that up and ask you how you felt about that after you had been there.
I didn't feel good at all.
That was a job that was put upon me.
I didn't volunteer for that.
Security police get all kinds of jobs like that.
So, you know, they had to have a high security clearance and all that good stuff.
No, I didn't like it.
You know, I did it like I was supposed to do it, but I didn't like doing it.
Were you supposed to have gone to Vietnam and done something grand and glorious over there?
I don't know.
I didn't see him.
You didn't see him.
Do you know what fragging is?
No.
Okay.
Do you have any views on why you think we lost the war?
I think we lost it because we pulled out.
Do you think we could have won it if we had stayed there?
Sure.
I think we could have won it any time we wanted to.
Why did you make that statement?
By they, who are you saying?
The politicians.
It was very political, no doubt about that.
Why did you think they didn't want to pull out?
They pulled out instead of letting us win, letting them win.
Why that we pulled out?
Instead of winning the war.
If you think they could have won the war.
Well, of course, I feel like that, you know, they could have won it before I ever went.
Anytime they wanted to.
And, you know, you know that.
We didn't use half of the firepower that we had available.
You know, we didn't use that in Vietnam.
Another thing, we never had went for territorial gain in Vietnam.
It was all body count type stuff.
So, you know, there wasn't that type of war.
I think any time that we had wanted to.
When I was there, most of the guys you talked to wanted to fight.
They wanted to go through and go on and keep going until we swept the country.
And everybody wanted to do that, but you couldn't do that.
And I think that could have been done in several months.
Why couldn't you?
Were you not allowed to?
No, I wasn't allowed.
It wasn't that kind of fighting.
Most everybody was assigned to a base.
You went out on patrol.
If you were in a reconnaissance group or you were in a combat infantry unit, you were sent out each day, and you might go through the same area every day for months.
And you didn't report that, well, we went four miles into the jungle today.
You reported body counts.
Did that disturb you?
Sure.
Why?
Well, we weren't making any progress.
In other words, did you safely say that you felt like you were spinning your wheels?
Sure, yeah.
Yeah, we were.
Take ceasefires, for instance.
Nobody in Vietnam wanted a ceasefire.
American troops didn't want ceasefires.
We had a ceasefire for Christmas.
Nobody wanted that.
Why not?
Because the North Vietnamese didn't honor ceasefires.
So you were just sitting there?
Sure.
What happened...
Everything you did before that time that that ceasefire was called, you pushed them back so far.
Well, they'd call a ceasefire so we couldn't do anything anymore but watch.
We could watch.
Everybody wanted to watch the enemy or whatever they were doing.
So during that ceasefire, nobody was supposed to move, do anything.
They would move all of their arms back south again, and we'd watch them.
convoys, miles long, moving ammunition and artillery back into the areas where we were.
When you immediately, after the ceasefire was over, we was going to get our tails blown off.
What you're saying is that the ceasefire, it was supposed to be arrest and recuperation or something like that, but you were actually setting you up as sitting ducks?
I think they were doing it for the people in the United States, not for us.
to satisfy that, not to, you know, it looked good on paper, in the news.
You know, Christmas ceasefire in Vietnam is a joke.
Did you, how much of the, what did you, how much did you know about Vietnam and what was going on in there?
Just what I saw on TV.
Which was what?
Well, you saw some...
